answers.answer: You have early hypothyroidism based on these labs -- seems to be a little more common in T2DM compared to non-DM patients.  The elevated Tg-Antibody suggests Hashimoto's (immune system attack causing chronic thyroid inflammation with subsequent under-activity).  Would recheck TSH and add TPO antibody to confirm the diagnosis.  A TSH of 4.59 does not always need treatment - talk to your endo about the pros/cons of levothyroxine.

question: I have Diabetes Type II, Left Bundle Branch Block.I have keep my sgar level between 80-115 most of the time and sometimes it goes higher.Went to see a new Endocrinologist because I wasextremely tired and exhausted feelingnails were brittle and splittinghair thinningweight gain about 15lbs in the last2 monthsdry eyeswake up with hands swellingdry skin hard to keep hands softbloatedconstipationslur speech or feel like tongue is in the way sometimesconfused and memory lossneck painMy blood test results from 2/4/08Thyroglobulin AB 134 (A)Thyroglobulin       0.5 (L)TSH                   4.59 (H)Cholesterol 172Triglycerides 84HDL 38LDL 117Hemoglobin A1c 6.2About 2 years ago my first endocrinologist, released me, because I had lost 50lbs, and controlled my sugar, but it was dropping in the 60's when I was working out. (He move to another state) June 20062-5-08 The new doctor told me to take 2000mg metformin a day. I started with 1000mg for a week and then up 2000mg for almost two weeks. I ended up in the hospital from severe vomitting and back and left arm pain. My cardio. said to stop taking metformin, but the endo. insist I keep taking it. I have not been taking them.My question is, do I  hypothyroid? Can you tell with these numbers above? And second question: should I continue to take the metformin after seeing the numbers and reaction above?Thank YouJstype2
title: Do I have hypothroid?
